syllabus:
**Objectives****:** This course is designed to support college freshmen in their use of **English language in an academic context** and to improve their **reading proficiency and vocabulary knowledge** through intensive and extensive reading and reading skill/strategy training. In addition, this class also aims to build up students’ proficiency in the other **three main language skills**—**writing, listening, and speaking**—through activities that integrate the four language skills. The objectives of this class include (1) developing students’ **effective English reading skills**, (2) **improving their fluency** in expressing ideas **in oral and written forms in English**, and (3) introducing **autonomous self-study skills** for their future learning. Therefore, there will be a five-pronged approach to the course:

**1) Firstly,** the **course textbook and online practice website** emphasize **vocabulary learning and building**. There is also a purposefully structured skills and strategies program to **propel language learning** and **create independent learners**. Furthermore, the textbook helps improve reading proficiency and **develop practical critical thinking.**

**2) Secondly,** over the course of the first-half of the semester, students will undertake **one major task-based project**, in which task groups, of no more than 4 students per group, are asked to **investigate areas and topics that are of interest to them**, and then **present their work to the class** via film, audio, or performance. Examples include short films (comedy, drama, horror), radio shows (news, weather, interviews, ads), plays (skits, drama, musicals), and shows (music, magic, games).

**3) Thirdly,** students will need to do at least **_10 hours_ of** **autonomous learning** in total this semester, and these experiences must be proven for grading.

**4) Finally**, there will be a **writing workshop** after which students will be asked to write **a short critical essay** based on class work.

**N.B:** All elements to the course will be evaluated and assessed for the final grade.

**Guidelines and Requirements: The Eight Commandments!**

1.  **Punctual attendance** is essential. Talk to or email me if you can’t attend class or are late for class.
2.  This is a **Flip Class**. Homework must be done for the class to work properly. This includes reviewing and previewing class chapters.
3.  Actively **participate in class discussions**.
4.  You need to **submit work _seven times_** during the semester. Task assignments, homework, and essays **must be done and be on time**.
5.  Smartphones, tablets, etc, must be **turned off** unless needed in class.
6.  **No eating** during class, but drinks are allowed.
7.  **English Practice**: Students should practice their English every chance they get, e.g. **Self-Access Room** (Main campus 樸101), **Workshops** (Main campus 樸102), the **Lexile Vocab Competition** and/or **iQOnlinePractice**. You are expected to do at least _10 hours_ in total this semester. Alternatively, you can **record autonomous work in your notebooks for grading.**
8.  **Grades will be downgraded** for failure to attend class without reason, excessive lateness, lack of participation or failure to do homework or assignments on time.

**Grading Policy****: The Business!**

Final grades are based and assessed on performance in the following:

**1)** Attendance and Participation: 10%

**2)** Task Project: 20% (Presentation: 10%, drafts and reflection: 10%)

**3)** Midterm Quiz: 10%

**4)** Book/Movie reviews & critical essays: 20%

**5)** Online learning/auto-learning: 20%

**6)** Final Exam: 20%
